bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, September 15, 1942

div1.p: Kean sends a copy of his introduction to Truby's memoir to Hench for his review.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, September 15, 1942
div1.opener:
answered 9/20/42
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.
Sept. 15, 1942
My dear Colonel Hench
div1.p:
You have doubtless learned that when
Esculapeus becomes the servant of Mars
he has a jealous master who demands
full time service of all the votaries
of the latter. Also as you left that
very efficient secretary of yours behind
you at Rochester, probably, a crimp
has been put in your style as a
correspondent. So I will not expect
much of you in that line for the dura-
tion. But you will have time I
think to glance over the Introduction
to Gen. Truby's memoir and I hope
you will like it as you figure so
largely in it, and will see that when
AC
K
2
I referred to your “catagorical inquisitions”
I said it with a smile, as was demanded
by that other Virginian in the novel By
Owen Wister.

As regards the publication of Truby's
memoir Gen Ireland has suggested,
as I may have written you, that
if the Surgeon General agrees to
order 1500 or 2000 copies, so as
to let each regular medical offi-
cer have one, there will be no
difficulty in getting a publisher.
Young Paul Huber who is now
with Harpers is anxious to get
it. The cost will depend largely
in the number of illustrations
they decide to put in. You and
Truby are more illustration-minded
3
than I am and are better able
to express an opinion of value.
Send me a line or two or even
a plebean post card, to acknowl-
edge this and say how you are
getting on. We had a pleasant
call from Mr. Kellogg and
Robin some ten days ago
